thread.title: David Cameron: I will set out renegotiation detail in November
thread.title_full: David Cameron: I will set out renegotiation detail in November

author: Matthew Holehouse
title: David Cameron: I will set out renegotiation detail in November
text:
EU Referendum David Cameron: I will set out renegotiation detail in November Prime Minister assures EU leaders he will "quicken the pace" and put a deal on the table next month At Chequers on Friday, Cameron warned Merkel that there was 'still much to be worked through' to reach an acceptable deal Photo: Reuters By Matthew Holehouse , in Brussels 1:46PM BST 15 Oct 2015 Follow 
David Cameron has promised to set out his EU renegotiation demands at the beginning of next month. 
The Prime Minister has come under growing pressure from his counterparts to provide a detailed, written list of demands, amid claims that Britain’s stance was deliberately vague. 
Arriving at a summit in Brussels, the Prime Minister bowed to demands to put his plans on the table, and insisted the renegotiation is “going well”, with the Referendum Bill now in the House of Lords. 
He said he will “quicken the pace” ahead of a summit in December, increasingly the likelihood of a referendum at some point in the middle of 2016. Diplomats had warned that the apparent slowdown in Britain would mean that summit would be little more than a “rendez-vous”, with no deal in sight until the March council at the earliest. 
“The pace will now quicken and I’ll begin setting out the four vital areas where we need change, laying down what those changes will be at the start of November,” Mr Cameron said. 
“So we quicken the pace and the quicker those negotiations in the run up to the December Council. I’m confident we can get a good deal for Britain we can fix these things that need to be fixed. I’m confident this process is well underway and making good progress.” 
EU officials had complained that the detailed legal work of the renegotiation was unable to begin without a text – withheld apparently for fear of leaks. Sources claimed they were told to read the Conservative manifesto and Mr Cameron's speeches to understand his demands, documents that are light on technical details. 
Mr Cameron has set out four 'baskets' of reform he wants: increasing competitiveness, a four-year waiting period on migrant benefits, protecting Britain from eurozone integration and reater powers for national parliaments. 
The remarks will help defuse what could have been a bruising row over dinner. Diplomatic sources had warned that several Prime Ministers were ready to confront Mr Cameron. 
He was speaking after a lunchtime meeting with Jean-Claude Juncker, the president of the European Council. He yesterday said that little progress had been made in technical talks running since June. 
"To tango it takes two. I am not a splendid dance, but at least I know the rules which have to be observed by others,” Mr Juncker told the European Parliament. “We have to dance, and our British friends have to dance.” 
Martin Schulz, the president of the European Parliament, said this morning: “I hope as far of the UK government is concerned and certainly with individuals and David Cameron, we can make steps forward. Above all we need clarity on what we are going to be discussing over the next few months." 
Angela Merkel and Francois Hollande had both pushed the Prime Minister to clarify what he wants at recent dinners at Chequers. Britain's struggle with Brussels Treaty of Paris creates the European Coal and Steel Community. Britain stays out. 1973 Britain, facing economic decline, enters the European Community. 1975 Membership reaffirmed in a national referendum The margin is 67.2 per cent. It comes after Harold Wilson promises a fundamental renegotiation of terms that, he insists, does not jeopardise national sovereignty. 1984 Rebate on EU contributions Margaret Thatcher during a press conference at the end of the European Economic Summit in 1984 (Photo: AP) Margaret Thatcher wields the handbag, and secures a rebate on Britain’s EU budget contributions. 1992 The Maastricht Treaty widens the European Union The treaty lays the framework for the Euro and shared foreign, social and justice policies. Its passage tears the Tory Party apart. 1997 The New Labour era begins Tony Blair opts into the social chapter, bringing the working time directive into force in Britain. Gordon Brown torpedoes membership of the Euro, which launches on January 1 2002. 2004 Eight Eastern European countries join the EU Citizens of eight Eastern European countries including Poland and Hungary get movement rights to Britain immediately. 2005 David Cameron wins the Tory leadership David Cameron and his wife Samantha wave to the audience after delivering his speech to the Annual Party Conference in 2005 (Picture: Bruno Vincent/Getty) He later tells his party to stop “banging on about Europe”. 2009 The Lisbon Treaty The treaty sees the creation of an EU president and Foreign Service, and removes Britain’s veto over 40 areas of policy. December 2011 David Cameron vetoes treaty to strengthen control over Eurozone He says it would jeopardise Britain’s access to the single market. January 2013 The Bloomberg speech David Cameron sets out a sweeping vision for reform to save Europe, highlighting the working time directive and Brussels’ bloated bureaucracy, followed by an in-out referendum in 2017. 1 January 2014 Greater freedoms for Bulgarians and Romanians Picture: Warren Allott/The Telegraph Bulgarians and Romanians given unrestricted right to travel and work in the EU after joining in 2007. Government responds with new laws to deport beggars and powers to end dole payments after six months. May 2014 Ukip come first in the European elections Photo: Peter Macdiarmid/Getty Images Over the summer, Tory MPs Douglas Carswell and Mark Reckless defect to Ukip. June 2014: Jean-Claude Juncker becomes president of the European Commission Most other member states backed Juncker's appointment (Photo: EPA) David Cameron is defeated in a bid to stop Jean-Claude Juncker becoming president of the European Commission by 26 to 2. November 2014 Cameron sets out his plan to reform EU migration It includes: denying migrants in-work benefits for four years and deporting unemployed EU migrants after six months. December 2014 ?1.7bn bill for EU membership Cameron is furious after Britain is hit with a ?1.7bn bill for EU membership, calculated due to the economy’s success compared to the Eurozone. May 7 2015 David Cameron wins the General Election His manifesto is based on reform and referendum. The renegotiation process is launched, and Cameron launches a whirlwind tour of Europe to visit all 27 counterparts. June 2015 Threat to use British budget contributions in emergency Greece loans In first unpleasant shock of the renegotiation, the European Commission threatens to use British budget contributions in emergency loans to Greece – tearing up a promise won by David Cameron four years previously. September 2015 Refugee crisis engulfs the continent Cameron is warned he will get nothing from his renegotiation unless he does more to tackle the crisis.
